title: Volleyball Passing Drill: Perfect Passes Repetition
description: This volleyball passing drill builds consistency, ball control, and defensive posture by focusing on perfect passes through high-repetition training.

setup.players: 2 passers, 2 tossers, 2 targets
setup.court: Half-court or designated passing zone
setup.roles: Tossers initiate play, passers receive and direct the ball, targets catch and rotate

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Roles: Tossers initiate play, passers receive and direct the ball, targets catch and rotate
The tosser uses a double overhead motion to toss the ball toward the passer.
The passer performs a controlled forearm pass to the designated target.
Rotate roles in sequence: tosser → passer → target → tosser.
Continue until the group achieves a set number of perfect passes (recommend 50–100 for high repetition).
Platform Control: Keep arms locked, wrists firm, and direct the pass to the target.
Engagement: Encourage open communication and quick role rotation to maintain a steady pace.
variations: Require the passer to use the overhead pass only for variation.
Add a time challenge (e.g., reach 50 perfect passes within 3 minutes).
Footwork: Shuffle quickly to get behind the ball instead of lunging.
coaching_tips: Deduct 1 point for every imperfect pass, encouraging precision and focus.
Stay Low: Maintain a ready position with knees bent and weight forward.
Consistency: Focus on repeatable form to build accuracy through high-volume reps.

title: Volleyball Serving Drill: Bombs Away! Short Serve Challenge
description: This volleyball serving drill improves short serve accuracy while challenging defenders to react quickly and anticipate ball flight.

setup.players: 3 servers, 3 passers
setup.court: Full court with passers starting on the end line opposite servers
setup.roles: Servers initiate play, passers defend and attempt to catch or pass the ball

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Court: Full court with passers starting on the end line opposite servers
Roles: Servers initiate play, passers defend and attempt to catch or pass the ball
Three servers line up on one side of the court, facing three passers on the end line.
Each server attempts to serve as short as possible without hitting the net.
Passers must wait on the end line until ball contact, then sprint forward and try to catch the ball before it hits the ground.
Scoring: The server earns 1 point if the ball lands untouched by the passer.
After each attempt, passers must return to the end line before the next serve.
Continue for a set time (2–3 minutes) before rotating servers and passers.
variations: Passing Target Variation: Instead of catching, passers must pass the ball to a designated target and remain in until they complete a set number of successful passes.

title: Volleyball Passing Drill: Passing Out of the Net
description: This volleyball passing drill teaches players to read and control balls rebounding off the net, improving anticipation, reaction, and ball control.

setup.players: 3 passers, 3 tossers
setup.court: Full court, passers lined up on the 10-foot line facing the net
setup.roles: Tossers send balls into the net, passers react and control the rebound pass

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Court: Full court, passers lined up on the 10-foot line facing the net
Roles: Tossers send balls into the net, passers react and control the rebound pass
Each tosser throws a ball over the passer’s head into the net, creating an unpredictable rebound.

Emphasize reading the ball off the net:
Top of the Net: Ball drops almost straight down.
Middle of the Net: Ball deflects outward slightly.
Continue for 8–10 reps per passer or about 3 minutes per round, then rotate roles.
Scoring System: Award points for accurate passes to a designated target zone.
Stay Low: Maintain bent knees and balanced posture.
Platform Control: Keep arms locked and angled toward the target—avoid swinging.
variations: Down Ball Variation: Tossers hit controlled down balls into the net instead of tossing.
Serve Variation: Servers serve into the net to create more unpredictable rebounds.
coaching_tips: Passers start in a low, ready position at the 10-foot line, facing the net.
The passer reads the rebound, stays low, and uses proper forearm passing technique to control the ball.

title: Volleyball Defense Drill: Touch Ten!
description: This volleyball defense drill builds aggressiveness and reading skills as defenders work to touch ten attacked balls before rotating out.

setup.players: 3 hitters, 1 setter, 1 defender, coach as tosser (additional defenders optional)
setup.court: Full court with hitters and setter on one side, defender on the opposite side
setup.roles: Coach tosses to setter, setter distributes sets, hitters attack, defender pursues and defends

Court: Full court with hitters and setter on one side, defender on the opposite side
Roles: Coach tosses to setter, setter distributes sets, hitters attack, defender pursues and defends
Coach stands on the sideline or backcourt, tossing balls to the setter.
The setter can set any of the three hitters with any type of set.
Hitters attempt to score by attacking balls away from the defender.
The defender may start anywhere on the court and must make contact with ten balls before rotating out.
Once the defender achieves ten touches, they switch with a new defender.
Adjust the goal for different levels: beginners may need only 3–5 touches, while advanced players should complete all 10 touches.
variations: Players: 3 hitters, 1 setter, 1 defender, coach as tosser (additional defenders optional)
Multiple Defenders: Add a second defender for teamwork and communication.
coaching_tips: Positioning: Start balanced and adjust quickly based on the set and hitter.

title: Volleyball Passing Warm-Up Drill: Passing Technique Path
description: This volleyball passing warm-up teaches players to stay low, move with control, and direct their platform to the target while improving footwork.

setup.players: Any number of players
setup.court: Half or full court with cones arranged in a W pattern
setup.roles: Passers move through cones, coach monitors technique

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Court: Half or full court with cones arranged in a W pattern
Equipment: Cones (volleyball optional for progression)
Continue along the W path until all cones are completed.
Repeat the pattern for a preset number of rounds (e.g., 3–5 full cycles per player). Each cycle should take about 1 minute.
Total drill duration: 5–7 minutes as part of warm-up.
Reverse Path: Run the W pattern in reverse to reinforce balance in both directions.
Stay Low: Keep your knees bent, weight forward, and chest over your toes.
Platform Control: Keep arms locked and angled toward the target at every cone.
coaching_tips: Roles: Passers move through cones, coach monitors technique
Players begin at the first cone and move from cone to cone in a low passing position.
At each cone, the player mimics a forearm pass to a target, focusing on keeping the platform angled correctly.
Coach Toss Progression: After the technique is established, the coach can toss a ball at each cone for players to pass to a target.
Timed Challenge: Have players complete the W pattern within a set time while maintaining technique.

title: Volleyball Defense Drill: 4-Corner Pit
description: This volleyball defensive drill improves quick reaction, aggressiveness, and movement as players chase balls directed into four court corners.

setup.players: 1 defensive player (2 for variation), coach or tosser on a box
setup.court: One side of the court with four corners marked with floor tape
setup.equipment: Volleyballs, box for coach/tosser to stand on
setup.roles: Coach (or player) directs balls into corners, defensive player pursues and makes contact

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Court: One side of the court with four corners marked with floor tape
Equipment: Volleyballs, box for coach/tosser to stand on
Roles: Coach (or player) directs balls into corners, defensive player pursues and makes contact
Mark the four corners of one side of the court with tape.
Coach (or player) stands on a box across the net and hits, tips, or tosses balls into the four corners.
Defensive players must make contact with every ball before it hits the ground.
If a ball lands untouched in a corner, assign a penalty (e.g., -1 point or conditioning).
Adjust difficulty: a slower pace emphasizes controlled contacts, while afaster pace turns it into conditioning.
variations: Players: 1 defensive player (2 for variation), coach or tosser on a box
Two-Player Version: Add a second defender to increase ball speed and demand communication.
Down Ball Variation: Coach uses tips or down balls instead of hard hits.
coaching_tips: Defensive player starts in the middle of the receiving court in a ready position.
Ready Position: Stay low, weight forward, and balanced on the balls of the feet.

title: Volleyball Serve Receive Drill with Two Servers
description: This volleyball drill improves serve receive by challenging players to pass short serves consistently to a target while rotating positions.

setup.players: 3 passers, 2 servers, 1 target, additional players in waiting lines
setup.court: Full court with emphasis on short serve zones
setup.roles: Servers initiate play, passers receive, target collects and resets, waiting players rotate in

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Roles: Servers initiate play, passers receive, target collects and resets, waiting players rotate in
Two servers alternate serving short to the passer group of three.
Passers must pass the ball to the target at the net.

Scoring:
+1 point for a successful pass to the target.
–1 point for a missed serve or a reception error (ball not playable by the target).
Extra players rotate in as servers or passers as needed.
Continue until the team reaches a set number of points (e.g., 15–20 points) or for a set duration (5–7 minutes per round).
Communication: Encourage loud, early calls for every ball.
Anticipation: Read the server’s toss, arm swing, and body angle to anticipate serve location.
variations: Players: 3 passers, 2 servers, 1 target, additional players in waiting lines
Team Competition: Instead of rotating players individually, divide into teams of three passers. Each team competes to reach a set number of successful passes first.
Zone Challenge: Servers aim for specific short zones to increase passer anticipation.
Error Pressure: Instead of -1 points, assign consequences for errors (e.g., 5 push-ups or a quick sprint).
coaching_tips: Court: Full court with emphasis on short serve zones
After both servers have served once (a total of 2 serves), the entire group rotates positions following the arrows.
Passing Technique: Maintain a firm platform and direct passes consistently to the target.
Game-Like Focus: Reinforce the importance of serve receive as the first touch that sets up offense.

title: Volleyball Passing Drill: 3-Touch Lateral Passing
description: This volleyball passing drill develops ball control and movement by training players to pass from midline and lateral positions with proper footwork.

setup.players: 3 passers active, 3 tossers, 3 passers waiting at serving line
setup.court: Half-court, with cones marking passer start points

Players: 3 passers active, 3 tossers, 3 passers waiting at serving line
Court: Half-court, with cones marking passer start points
Roles: Tossers feed balls, passers execute passing reps, waiting passers rotate in
The tosser initiates the first ball back and to the passer’s right.
Passer retreats and performs a right-side lateral pass back to the tosser.
The tosser then tosses a ball toward the passer’s midline.
Passer retreats and executes a forearm pass to the tosser.
The tosser tosses the final ball back and to the passer’s left.
variations: Add a scoring system for perfect passes to a target zone.
Increase the speed of tosses to force quicker reaction time.

title: Volleyball Passing Drill: Pass and Move
description: This volleyball passing drill trains players to move laterally, square to the target, and pass under game-like movement pressure.

setup.players: 1 active passer with a line of waiting passers, 2 tossers
setup.court: Half court, focusing on right-back to mid-court movement
setup.roles: Tossers initiate balls, passers move and execute passes before rotating

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Players: 1 active passer with a line of waiting passers, 2 tossers
Roles: Tossers initiate balls, passers move and execute passes before rotating
As the passer retreats, Tosser 2 tosses the next ball for the passer to handle.
The passer receives another toss from Tosser 1, then backpedals into the waiting line.
Suggested reps: Each passer completes 2–3 full cycles (6–9 passes total), about 1–2 minutes of work per round.
Reverse Direction: Run the same sequence starting from the left side.
Square to Target: Passers must face the target before contacting the ball.
Stay Low: Keep knees bent and weight forward while moving.
variations: Blocking Addition: Add practice blocks when crossing the net before passing.
Speed Challenge: Increase the tempo of tosses to demand quicker movement.
Footwork: Emphasize shuffling and controlled retreating instead of lunging.
coaching_tips: Court: Half court, focusing on right-back to mid-court movement
Start with a passer in the right-back base position.
After passing, the passer sprints forward to touch the tosser’s foot, then retreats diagonally back into the next base position.
After the second pass, the passer sprints behind Tosser 2, then shuffles laterally across in a ready position.
Common Game Situation: Prepares players for serve receive and defensive rallies that require quick movement between positions.

title: Volleyball Passing Drill: Pass and Weave
description: This volleyball passing drill develops ball control, lateral footwork, and passing accuracy while keeping players low and balanced in movement.

Roles: Tossers feed balls, passer moves and executes passes, waiting players rotate in
Place 3 volleyballs or cones in a straight line to act as weaving markers.
Tosser 1 tosses a ball, and the passer executes a controlled pass to the target.
After passing, the passer shuffles and weaves around the first ball/cone.
Tosser 2 tosses a ball; the passer squares up and passes to the target.
variations: Increase Difficulty: Add more tossers and markers for extended movement.
coaching_tips: Passer begins in a low, ready position in front of Tosser 1.

setup.players: 1 server, 6-player serve receive team, 3 blockers
setup.court: Full court, standard 6v6 serve receive rotation setup

Players: 1 server, 6-player serve receive team, 3 blockers
Court: Full court, standard 6v6 serve receive rotation setup
Roles: Server initiates, serve receive team passes/sets/hits, blockers challenge at the net
Receiving team lines up in their first rotation serve receive formation.
Blockers on the serving side attempt to block every attack.
Switch servers when the receiving team successfully rotates.
Suggested reps: Run drill for 15–20 minutes or until every player has completed a full rotation.
Passing First: Remind players that everything starts with a strong, controlled pass.
variations: Adjust Swing Requirement: Increase or decrease the number of consecutive swings (e.g., 2 for beginners, 4–5 for advanced).
Alternative Goal: Instead of swings, require the setter to run the middle or right-side attacker three times in a row.
Scoring Variation: Award points for kills or blocked swings to create a competitive element between offense and defense.
coaching_tips: The serve-receive team must achieve 3 consecutive hard swings in a row (balls attacked over the net with pace and in-bounds) before they can rotate positions.
Continue until the receiving team rotates all the way around through all positions.

Roles: Partners exchange controlled down balls in a continuous sequence
Players stand cross-court from each other on opposite sides of the net.
One player initiates the drill with a down ball to their partner.
Receiving player must pass to self, set to self, and down ball back cross-court to their partner.
Continue the rally in this cross-court pepper pattern.
Suggested reps: Rally for 30–60 seconds continuously, rest briefly, then repeat for 4–6 rounds (8–10 minutes total).
Overhead First Contact: Require the first contact to be an overhead pass before setting.
variations: Approach Variation: Players must take a full approach before hitting to their partner.
Extended Distance: Move players farther apart to increase difficulty and reaction time.
coaching_tips: Players: 2 players positioned cross-court from each other on opposite sides of the net
Target Focus: Players should always face their target when contacting the ball.
Footwork: Stay balanced and in a ready position for each contact.

Players: 3 active players on each side (middle back, setter, outside hitter), with a line of players waiting to rotate in at middle back
Coach initiates play by sending a free ball to the middle back.
Outside hitter executes a controlled attack or down ball to the opposite middle back.
Players follow their ball:Passer → becomes setterSetter → becomes hitterHitter → goes to end of the middle back line
Rally continues with the same sequence on both sides of the net.
Teams count contacts aloud, aiming for 25 total successful contacts before the other team.

title: Volleyball Hitting Drill: Turn, Go, and Hit Transition
description: This volleyball hitting drill practices defensive movement, diving recovery, and transitioning into an attacking approach against a live block.

setup.players: 1 hitter/defender, 1 tosser, 1 blocker, line of waiting players
setup.court: Full court, focused on right-side sideline to left transition
setup.roles: Hitter performs defensive and offensive actions, blocker defends and rotates, tosser initiates play

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Players: 1 hitter/defender, 1 tosser, 1 blocker, line of waiting players
Roles: Hitter performs defensive and offensive actions, blocker defends and rotates, tosser initiates play
The player begins on the right sideline, shuffles twice toward the center of the court.
The player then turns and sprints to the opposite (left) sideline.
At the sideline, the player dives and touches the ball, then recovers quickly.
The tosser delivers a toss, and the player performs a full hitting approach and attack.
The blocker on the opposite side attempts to block the attack.
The blocker retrieves the ball and rotates to the end of the line; the hitter becomes the new blocker.
variations: Add a second blocker for more realistic game pressure.
Require hitters to tip or roll shots after the dive instead of always hitting.
coaching_tips: Court: Full court, focused on right-side sideline to left transition
After getting up, the player transitions into hitting position.
Body Positioning: Ensure players turn their shoulders to face the target when transitioning.
Explosiveness: Focus on a quick first step out of the dive and into the hitting transition.
Hitting Technique: Reinforce proper approach, footwork, timing, and follow-through.

title: Volleyball Warm-Up Drill: Tag Team Warm-Up

Players: 3 active players inside the 10-foot line; 3 lines of players waiting behind the end line
Roles: Coach initiates play, active players execute pass–set–tip sequence, waiting players tag in
Coach begins by tossing a free ball or down ball into play, alternating sides of the court.
Active players execute a sequence: pass → set → tip the ball into the 10-foot line area on the opposite side.
After making contact, the player must run back, tag a teammate, and rotate out.
Tagged player enters the drill immediately, maintaining only 3 players on the court inside the 10-foot line at a time.
Rally scoring is used to track points, with a set goal (e.g., play to 10 or 15).
Suggested reps: Run 2–3 games of 8–10 minutes each, ensuring all players get multiple rotations.
variations: Add Defense: Place a back row defender on each side to dig tipped balls and extend rallies.
Attacking Option: Allow attackers to swing hard instead of tipping for advanced groups.
Speed Challenge: Reduce time allowed for tagging in to increase pace and conditioning.
coaching_tips: Technique: Emphasize controlled passes, clean sets, and accurate tips to target areas.

title: Volleyball Free Ball Drill: Transition and Catch
description: This volleyball free ball drill teaches players how to transition quickly and correctly into free ball positions while reinforcing communication and court awareness.

setup.players: 6 players on the court in defensive base positions

description: This volleyball ball control drill develops communication, teamwork, and consistency as players pass, set, and hit while working together to reach 24 consecutive touches.

Court: Full court, each side operating independently
Middle back passes to the setter and follows the ball to become the new setter.
Setter sets the outside hitter, then follows the ball to become the new outside hitter.
Outside hitter executes a controlled down ball over the net, then rotates to the back of the line on their side.
Continue the cycle with new players stepping in and repeating the sequence.
The team works together to achieve 24 consecutive touches. If the ball drops, the count restarts.
Suggested reps: Run for 8–10 minutes, or until the team successfully completes 24 touches.
variations: Timed Challenge: Instead of touches, require teams to sustain play for a set time (e.g., 3 minutes).
coaching_tips: Coach: Positioned with volleyballs to toss in free balls
Controlled Contacts: Focus on clean, accurate passes and sets that keep rhythm.
Encouragement: Have players count touches out loud to reinforce focus and teamwork.

title: Volleyball Passing Drill: Middle or Lateral Decision-Making
description: This volleyball passing drill improves serve receive, ball control, and decision-making between inside-the-body and lateral passing.

setup.players: 2 passers, 2 servers, 2 targets
setup.court: Half-court (one side passers, one side servers)
setup.equipment: Volleyballs, cones to mark passer shuffle lanes

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Court: Half-court (one side passers, one side servers)
Equipment: Volleyballs, cones to mark passer shuffle lanes
Roles: Passers receive, servers initiate play, targets catch and reset balls
Servers alternate sending a ball to the passers, varying serves between inside (toward the middle) or outside (toward the sideline).
If the serve is inside the body, the passer shuffles and performs a controlled pass from the midline of their body to the target.
After completing the pass, the passer shuffles back behind the cones and prepares for the next serve.
Movement: Stress-shuffling before reaching, rather than lunging, to maintain control.
Decision-Making: Passers must quickly adjust based on serve location (midline vs lateral).
variations: Start the sequence with a toss or down ball instead of a serve for beginners.
Add a time constraint (e.g., must pass 5 balls in 30 seconds) to increase urgency.
Place an additional server in the corner to create more unpredictable serve angles.
coaching_tips: If the serve is toward the sideline, the passer shuffles and uses a lateral passing technique to redirect the ball to the target.
Each passer completes a set number of repetitions (e.g., 8–10 passes) before rotating positions.
Body Position: Emphasize correct stance, shuffling quickly, and facing the target.
Passing Technique: Contact the ball on the forearms, keep wrists firm, and angle the platform to the target.

description: This volleyball drill creates a fun game scenario where one team can only set and the other can only pass, improving control and teamwork under scoring pressure.

Court: Half-court or full-court setup, depending on group size
Tosser initiates the drill with an easy toss to the right back passer.
Passer makes a controlled pass to the setter, then follows their ball to become the new setter.
Setter delivers a consistent set to the outside hitter, then follows the ball to become the new outside hitter.
Outside hitter catches the set and bounce-passes it under the net to the tosser, then rotates to the back of the passer line.
Tosser maintains tempo by quickly tossing the next ball with minimal delay.
Tougher Tosses: The Tosser serves or tosses tougher balls to challenge passers.
Time Pressure: Run drill with a countdown (e.g., get 30 successful pass-set sequences in 3 minutes).
variations: Line: Additional players form a line behind the serving line waiting to rotate in as passers
Live Attack: Instead of catching, the outside hitter tips or rolls the ball back over the net.
coaching_tips: Players: 4 positions: right back passer, setter, outside hitter (catches sets), and tosser on opposite side
Suggested reps: Each player should complete 8–10 full rotations through all positions or run for 10–12 minutes total.

title: Volleyball Blocking Drill: Net Decision
description: This volleyball blocking drill trains players to read the ball at the net and decide whether to block, attack an overpass, or step back and pass.

setup.players: 3 blockers, 3 tossers
setup.court: Full court, with tossers on one side of the net and blockers opposite
setup.roles: Tossers create different ball trajectories into the net area; blockers read and respond appropriately

Court: Full court, with tossers on one side of the net and blockers opposite
Roles: Tossers create different ball trajectories into the net area; blockers read and respond appropriately
A tosser tosses a ball across the net in varying scenarios:Tight to the netOn top of the tapeJust over the net
The blocker must decide whether to:Jump and blockAttack the overpass with a controlled swingStep back and pass the ball with control
After each contact, the blocker resets quickly for the next ball.
Suggested reps: Each blocker completes 8–12 decision reps per round or 2–3 minutes of continuous work, then rotates.
Middle Transition: Require the middle blocker to shuffle outside to form a double block with pin hitters.
Decision-Making: Emphasize reading the ball trajectory quickly to choose the correct action.
variations: Continue tossing balls with variation to keep the blocker reading and reacting.
Double Block: Add a second blocker to work on forming a strong, unified block.
Scoring System: Award points for correct decisions and clean execution to add competition.
coaching_tips: Position three tossers on one side of the net and three blockers on the other.
Hand Position: Blockers must keep their hands up and ready at all times.
Aggressiveness with Control: Players should commit fully to their choice while keeping technique sound.

Start with 3 target players spread out along the net with a ball each.
Set ploy markers in front of each target player about 10 feet from the target player, and along the end line.
When he approaches the marker the target player throws a ball that is returned by the working player.
The working player then shuffles to the middle cone, the target player throws a ball to them, and they return it to that target player.
They then backpedal to the cone behind them along the end line, touch the cone, and sprintdiagonallyto the 3rd target player.
The target player tosses the ball to the working player who returns the ball to this target player.
Once the ball is returned, the working player sprints around the outside of the court and returns to the line.
Modify the contact type: setting, bumping, tomahawk, spike.
coaching_tips: The remaining players start at the server position.
The first player in line at the server position sprints forward towards the target player in front of them.
Proper technique for each of the contact types

Start with a basket of volleyballs for the coach to toss.
The first two players start on their stomachs with eyes down.
The drill starts with two lines of players in the middle back area of the court.
The first player in each line starts on their stomach looking down at the ground.
The player who passed the ball, shags the ball and returns to the end of the shortest line.
The player who did not pass, gets back down and ready for the next turn.

To take it to the next level, have the players on their belly turn around to where they are facing the line of waiting players. This makes it harder for them to hear the signal, jump up, and find the ball before having to make a pass.
You can also run this drill by having the first player who passes the ball to pass it straight up in the middle of the court, then the second player should then pass it over the net.  TEAMWORK.
coaching_tips: When the coach signals (a slap of the ball, whistle, etc) the players quickly get to their feet in ready position and calls the tossed ball, then passing it to the target.
Coaches can also run this drill by hitting down balls at the players when they are in ready position.
Coaches are watching for correct form. Players should be able to move and position themselves to where their shoulders are facing the target.

Players: 1 setter and 1 middle back per side, with lines of players behind each middle back

Middle back executes a controlled back row attack directed at the opposing middle back.
Players rotate by following their ball but staying on their own side:Middle back → SetterSetter → End of the lineEnd of line → Middle back
Continue rally exchanges for a set number of contacts (e.g., 20–25 contacts) or by time (e.g., 3–5 minutes per round).

Split the team into groups of 4 with 1 ball per group.
The group of 4 players stand in a line about 10 yards apart with two players standing in the middle with their backs to each other.
One of the outside players will start with the ball.
The outside player tosses the ball up and sets the ball to the middle player facing them, who returns it back to the starting player.
The starting player now sets the ball to the farthest player and switches with this middle player.
The other outside player now in possession of the ball follows the same pattern and sets it to the middle player who returns it to the same outside player.
The ball is again set to the farthest outside player and switches roles with the middle player facing them.
coaching_tips: Focus on good setting technique to the target.

title: Individual Setting Drill
description: This is a individual volleyball setting drill that focuses on setting ball control and overhead passes. This setting drill can be performed at home or during training.

Each player works on setting/overhead passes on their own. This will allow for the maximum number of contacts in a short period of time.
Each player performs 30continuousoverhead/setting passes to themselves 30 times while not allowing the ball to touch the ground.
Repeat the contacts for 30 times. This time every set should go about 6-feet above the player's head.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, have the player make a 6-inch set followed by a 6-foot set and alternate between the each contact.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, have the player spin 90 degrees after each set pass.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, mark off an area with polyspot markers and the player must perform all of the overhead passes/sets inside this area.
Make the players start over at 1 each time the ball hits the floor until they reach the set number of contacts.
Feet shoulder width apart or slightly wider with one foot slightly ahead of the other
variations: You can increase or decrease the number of contacts based on the skill level of the players.

Set two target players with a ball each near the attack line.
Set two poly spot markers near the end line on each side of the court.
The passers start at the marker near the right side of the court.
The target player in front of the passers tosses a ball to the first passer in line.

The passer returns the ball with a pass back to the target player and sprints to the attack line near the target, touches the line with their hand, and continues to the marker on the left end line of the court.
The next target player tosses a ball to the passer who again returns the ball to the same target player.
The passer then sprints to the net, shuffles across the court at the net while jumping up 3 times to simulate blocking.
The drill should be fluid and the next passer should start as the first target player receives their return pass.
coaching_tips: Focus on good passing technique, moving after the pass, getting height at the net.

One player is working while the other player is only responsible for tossing the ball to the working player.
The thrower will toss a ball to the passing player who simply returns a forearm pass back to the thrower.
Have the players switch roles after a predefined time or after a certain number of contacts.
Have the passing player move 2-3 steps to the right, left, back, or front and the thrower should toss the ball to the new spot and have the passer return the ball after moving.
coaching_tips: Players should position themselves about 10 to 20 feet apart depending on the skill level of the players.
Thrower should position themselves near the net and the passer facing the net.
The thrower should catch the ball and repeat. By having the thrower catch the ball the passer can focus on receiving a clean ball and focus on ball control.
Focus on good clean forearm contact.

title: Volleyball Pepper Drill: Two-Way Pepper

Players: 2 back row players on each side of the net (4 total)
Court: Half-court or backcourt area divided by the net
Roles: Pairs work together in a continuous pepper sequence
Start with one side sending a down ball straight across to the player in front of them.
That player passes to themselves, sets to themselves, and hits a down ball cross-court to the opposite side.
The receiving players then pass to themselves, set to themselves, and hit straight across.
Continue the rally, alternating straight across from one side and cross-court from the other side.
Suggested reps: Each group should rally for 30–60 seconds continuously, rest briefly, then repeat for 4–6 rounds (about 8–10 minutes total).
variations: Approach Variation: Players must take a full hitting approach before contacting the ball.

Ball Control: Emphasize controlled contacts instead of power.
coaching_tips: Place two players on each side of the net in back row positions.

title: Individual Forearm Passing Drill
description: This is a individual passing drill that is intended to focus on learning the forearm pass and ball control with the forearm. This is a drill that can be done at home or in the gym during training.

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Each player works on forearm passes on their own with a volleyball each. This will allow for the maximum number of contacts in a short period of time.
Each player performs 30continuousforearm passes to themselves 30 times while not allowing the ball to touch the ground.
Repeat the contacts for 30 times. This time every pass should go about 5 feet above the player's head.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, have the player make a 6 inch pass followed by a 5 foot pass and alternate between the each contact.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, have the player spin 90 degrees after each pass.
Repeat the contacts again for 30 times. This time, have the player start in a low squat and touch the floor between each pass to themselves.
Make the players start over at 1 each time the ball hits the floor until they reach the set number of contacts.
Make sure each of the passes are performed with the forearms.
variations: You can increase or decrease the number of contacts based on the skill level of the players.

Team A starts with two serves in a row. Each rally is played out normally.

After two serves, the opposing team gets two serves. Continue alternating.

Coach initiates each rally with a free ball toss, alternating sides.
Teams play out rallies as in a normal game, but only back row players are allowed to attack.
To rotate, a team must win 2 consecutive points (a “wash”).
Teams continue rotating in standard volleyball rotation rules.
The first team to complete a full team rotation is the winner.
Suggested reps: Play 1–2 full team rotations, or run for 15–18 minutes depending on practice length.
Advanced Play: Require 3–5 consecutive points for rotation.

Coach stands just inside the court with left foot on the end line.
Coach tosses a low ball (antennae height) slightly in front of the server.

Server completes swing, lands inside the court, and rotates to the back of the line.

description: This defensive volleyball drill trains the middle back player to move quickly into position, anticipate attacks, and return playable balls with proper forearm passing technique.

On the coach’s command, the middle back makes an arching run into the right defensive zone in low posture.
As the defender arrives, the right-side hitter attacks a ball into that zone.
Defender immediately sprints around the starting cone and makes another arching run into the left defensive zone.
Left-side hitter attacks, and the middle back again returns the ball with a forearm pass.
Continue alternating sides for 8–10 reps per defender, or for a 60-second timed round before rotating players.
Shaggers collect balls to keep the drill fast-paced.
Require passes to be directed to a target on the opposite side of the net.
variations: Players: 1 middle back defender, 2 hitters, additional players to shag balls
coaching_tips: Court Layout:Place the middle back at the baseline in the center.Set a pollyspot at the starting position.Place two markers 5–7 feet apart from the baseline (left and right zones).Position two hitters at the net, one on each sideline, with a supply of balls.
Middle back passes the ball using proper forearm passing technique back into play.

The pattern continues until an error is made or coach stops the drill.

Form multiple teams of 3 players each. Two teams begin on the court, one per side, with others waiting behind each serving line.

After a successful rally, the ball is sent over the net, and the team that just attacked rotates off and goes behind the opposite baseline.
If a team makes an error (missed pass, illegal attack, out of bounds, or failure to stay behind the 10-foot line), they are eliminated and replaced by the next team in line.
When only two teams remain, they play one final rally to determine the winner.
Suggested reps: Play until a team earns 5–7 points, or for 12–15 minutes total.

title: Volleyball Offense Drill: Kill Drill
description: This volleyball drill emphasizes the importance of terminating rallies with a kill, training hitters to attack aggressively while defenders work to extend plays.

setup.players: 3 hitters in offensive lines, 1 setter, 3 back-row defenders, 3 front-row defenders
setup.court: Full court, with offense on one side and defense on the other
setup.roles: Coach tosses to setter, hitters attack, defense works to dig and block

Players: 3 hitters in offensive lines, 1 setter, 3 back-row defenders, 3 front-row defenders
Court: Full court, with offense on one side and defense on the other
Roles: Coach tosses to setter, hitters attack, defense works to dig and block
Hitter executes a full approach and aggressive attack.
Scoring & Rotation:If the hitter scores a kill, they remain on offense and earn 1 point.If the hitter does not score, they rotate off to the back row of the defensive side.
Defensive players rotate forward: back row → front row → hitting line.
Continue until the offense reaches a predetermined number of points (e.g., 15 points).
Suggested reps: Run for 10–12 minutes per round, ensuring every player rotates through offense and defense multiple times.
variations: Play It Out: Allow the defense to continue the rally instead of stopping on first contact.
coaching_tips: Defensive Focus: Defenders must be disciplined, ready to dig, and anticipate swings.

title: Setting Drill - Triangle
description: This setting drill will focus on setting and passing overhead from different angles on the net and passing back to these targets.
steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
One target player has a ball one the side of the setter.
Another target player starts behind setter with a ball.
One target player tosses the ball to the setter who sets it back to that target player.
Immediately upon returning the first set, the next player tosses the ball to the setter who sets it back to that target player.
Continue with this pattern until the setter is comfortable setting along the net as well as back setting.
Change the distance and angles of the target players.
Feet shoulder width apart or slightly wider with one foot slightly ahead of the other
Knees bent slightly & weight evenly distributed on the balls of feet

title: Line Hitting Drill
description: This volleyball hitting drill focuses on hitting down the line as well as getting into a passing rhythm setting up the shot down the line.
steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Set up 3 players on each side of the court. A line defender, a setter, and a hitter.
The coach throws a free ball to the line defender on one side of the court who passes to the setter.
The setter then sets to the hitter along the side line.
The hitter plays a ball down the line towards the line defender.
The play should continue until the ball is dropped.
Change up the location of the players to match your offense or defense.
coaching_tips: The line defender should position themselves and defend the line opposite the hitter.
Have the players rotate positions every contact following the path of their ball.
Focus on bump, set, hitting techniques.

title: Volleyball Setting and Overhead Passing Warm-Up Dril
description: This volleyball warm-up drill develops setting and overhead passing skills while adding movement, teamwork, and game-like pressure.

setup.players: Two teams of 6 players.
setup.court: Full court with a net.
setup.equipment: Supply of volleyballs with the coach positioned at the net to initiate play.
setup.roles: All players are passers/setters; the coach serves as the initiator.

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Roles: All players are passers/setters; the coach serves as the initiator.
The coach begins each rally by tossing a ball into play, alternating sides.
Players may only use the overhead pass (set) to keep the ball in play.
After completing an overhead pass, the player must sprint to the end line and return before rejoining the play.
Teams score using rally scoring, playing to 10 points.
Players can return the ball on the first, second, or third contact.
Require teams to return the ball only on the third contact to encourage better ball movement and communication.
Reduce team size to 4 players per side for more touches and conditioning.
variations: Add a time limit sprint (e.g., reach the end line and back in 5 seconds) to increase intensity.
coaching_tips: Equipment: Supply of volleyballs with the coach positioned at the net to initiate play.
Positioning: Feet shoulder-width apart, one slightly forward, knees bent, balanced on the balls of the feet.
Technique: Contact the ball at the forehead, using full-body extension (legs and arms) to guide the ball.

title: Volleyball 3v3 Drill - Reading the Block
description: This 3v3 volleyball drill teaches hitters to read and react to blockers, improving offensive decision-making, communication, and ball control.

setup.players: Two teams of 3 (3v3).Team A (Offense): Passer, setter, hitter.Team B (Defense): 2 blockers, 1 passer.
setup.equipment: Rack of volleyballs for continuous play.

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Drills by SkillVolleyball Warm-Up DrillsVolleyball Ball Control DrillsVolleyball Blocking DrillsVolleyball Defense DrillsVolleyball Down Balls DrillsVolleyball Hitting DrillsVolleyball Middle Hitter DrillsVolleyball Offense DrillsVolleyball Outside Hitter DrillsVolleyball Passing DrillsVolleyball Pass-Set-Hit DrillsVolleyball Pepper Drills DrillsVolleyball Serve Defense DrillsVolleyball Serving DrillsVolleyball Setting DrillsVolleyball Fitness Drills
Players: Two teams of 3 (3v3).Team A (Offense): Passer, setter, hitter.Team B (Defense): 2 blockers, 1 passer.
Equipment: Rack of volleyballs for continuous play.
Coach initiates the drill with a free ball toss over the net to the offensive team.
As the ball is tossed, the coach calls out whether the defense should block or pull off the net.
Offensive team passes, sets, and attacks, reacting to the defensive decision.
Defensive team plays the rally with 2 blockers and a passer.
Suggested: Play for 10–12 rallies per group or 3–4 minutes before switching sides.
Allow the defensive team to choose freely whether to block or not, forcing the offense to read cues.
coaching_tips: Run the drill with focus on the blockers, emphasizing hand positioning, timing, and communication.
Passers and setters should focus on tempo and ball placement to give the hitter options.

title: Volleyball Blocking Drill: Double Block Attacking
description: This volleyball drill trains hitters to attack against a double block while blockers refine positioning, timing, and footwork to shut down the offense.

setup.players: Attacking side: 6 players (setter, passers, and hitters)Defending side: 4 blockers at the net, 1 server, and 2 back-row defenders
setup.court: Full court
setup.roles: Defending side initiates serve; blockers form a double block; attackers work to score against the block

steps: Drills by AgeBeginner Volleyball DrillsMiddle School / Jr High Volleyball DrillsHigh School Volleyball DrillsCollege Volleyball Drills

Players:Attacking side: 6 players (setter, passers, and hitters)Defending side: 4 blockers at the net, 1 server, and 2 back-row defenders
Roles: Defending side initiates serve; blockers form a double block; attackers work to score against the block
Defending side begins with a serve to the attacking side.
Attacking side runs an offensive play against the double block.
If the attacking side gets the ball past the block, the defending side continues to play the rally out with its defenders.
The 4th blocker (right side) steps off the court after the serve to open space, re-entering when the ball transitions back to the attacking side.
Attacking side works toward a set goal (e.g., 3 kills out of 5 swings or 7 out of 10 swings).
Suggested reps: Run 2–3 rounds of 10 attacks per side, lasting about 6–8 minutes per round.
coaching_tips: Blockers: Focus on footwork, timing, and hand positioning to close the block.
